text:
St. Cyprian's Protestant Episcopal Church, 165-171 West
63rd Street, north side, east of Amsterdam Avenue.
October 14, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.

202 and 204-06 West 63rd Street, adjoining and west of the S.W. corner of Amsterdam Ave., sowing the Union Baptist Church at No. 204-06. View No. 2 shows the 4-story structure (No. 202) that is the Lincoln House. This Church organized in 1889 by Dr. Sims is moving to a new place of worship in West 145th Street and these quarters will be occupied by Father Divines Peace Mission in 1937.

October 14, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

202 and 204-06 West 63rd Street, adjoining and west of the S.W. corner of Amsterdam Ave., sowing the Union Baptist Church at No. 204-06. View No. 2 shows the 4-story structure (No. 202) that is the Lincoln House. This Church organized in 1889 by Dr. Sims is moving to a new place of worship in West 145th Street and these quarters will be occupied by Father Divines Peace Mission in 1937.

October 14, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

(1) and (2)
West 63rd Street, west from Amsterdam Ave., to the North (Hudson) River. At the left is Father Divine's Peace Mission occupying a structure (No. 204-08) which formerly was the Union Baptist Church. To the east of same and adjoining the structure at the S.W. corner of Amsterdam Ave. is a 4-story building that formerly was Lincoln House; a unit of the aforementioned Church. No. 2 of this set shows these two solely. In the center of this block (and facing clearance on the north side) just west of the large apartment house shown is an industrial school (No. 220) maintained by the Childrens Aid Society.

November 30, 1937.

P.L. Sperr.

(3)
A view showing the last mentioned feature prominently (left).
November 30, 1937.

P.L. Sperr.

(1) and (2)
West 63rd Street, west from Amsterdam Ave., to the North (Hudson) River. At the left is Father Divine's Peace Mission occupying a structure (No. 204-08) which formerly was the Union Baptist Church. To the east of same and adjoining the structure at the S.W. corner of Amsterdam Ave. is a 4-story building that formerly was Lincoln House; a unit of the aforementioned Church. No. 2 of this set shows these two solely. In the center of this block (and facing clearance on the north side) just west of the large apartment house shown is an industrial school (No. 220) maintained by the Childrens Aid Society.

November 30, 1937.

P.L. Sperr.

(3)
A view showing the last mentioned feature prominently (left).
November 30, 1937.

P.L. Sperr.

(1) and (2)
West 63rd Street, west from Amsterdam Ave., to the North (Hudson) River. At the left is Father Divine's Peace Mission occupying a structure (No. 204-08) which formerly was the Union Baptist Church. To the east of same and adjoining the structure at the S.W. corner of Amsterdam Ave. is a 4-story building that formerly was Lincoln House; a unit of the aforementioned Church. No. 2 of this set shows these two solely. In the center of this block (and facing clearance on the north side) just west of the large apartment house shown is an industrial school (No. 220) maintained by the Childrens Aid Society.

November 30, 1937.

P.L. Sperr.

(3)
A view showing the last mentioned feature prominently (left).
November 30, 1937.

P.L. Sperr.

210-212 W. 63rd Street (6 story tenement), south side, of Amsterdam Avenue, as viewed southward from 64th Street and across a vacant area between same and 63rd Street.
To the right and left of the enumerated structure are respectively, the Children's Aid Society (formerly given as the Industrial School) and the former Union Baptist Church.  The latter is now occupied by followers of a colored evangelist "Father Divine".  Note the utilization of the cleared area on the North side of W. 63rd Street for a playground for children of the neighborhood.
July 15, 1938

P. L. Sperr
